channel.title: Comments on: User Agent Sniffing at Google Libraries CDN

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/11/01/user-agent-sniffing-at-google-libraries-cdn/#comment-3569">Maria Smith</a>.
Each browser behaves a bit differently, and it is entirely possible that your CDN is treating different browsers differently.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Maria Smith.

Each browser behaves a bit differently, and it is entirely possible that your CDN is treating different browsers differently.

item.title: By: Maria Smith
item.dc:creator: Maria Smith
item.description: Does Google's CDN work well while using particular browser? (I mean Chrome of course). I've just recently found that my site's speed is different in different browsers. I'm using cdnsun and I've found that site works more productive in Mozilla only. So, tell me guys: may google's cdn show the best of it in chrome? Thanks.
item.content:encoded: Does Google’s CDN work well while using particular browser? (I mean Chrome of course). I’ve just recently found that my site’s speed is different in different browsers. I’m using cdnsun and I’ve found that site works more productive in Mozilla only. So, tell me guys: may google’s cdn show the best of it in chrome? Thanks.

item.title: By: Federico
item.dc:creator: Federico
item.description: good post! I'm using Firefox 3.6.13 and asking for http://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.4.2/jquery.min.js I receive an uncompressed file... ...but using https https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.4.2/jquery.min.js the returned file is definitely compressed. There's something wrong in their white list approach. I wonder why not trusting the request headers? Federico
item.content:encoded:
good post!
I’m using Firefox 3.6.13 and asking for
http://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.4.2/jquery.min.js
I receive an uncompressed file…
…but using https
https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.4.2/jquery.min.js
the returned file is definitely compressed.
There’s something wrong in their white list approach.
I wonder why not trusting the request headers?
Federico

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/11/01/user-agent-sniffing-at-google-libraries-cdn/#comment-3566">Thomas Scholz</a>.
I'm not sure about the empty Location header, but the 'X-Cnection' appears to be a load balancer - http://www.nextthing.org/archives/2005/08/07/fun-with-http-headers
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Thomas Scholz.

I’m not sure about the empty Location header, but the ‘X-Cnection’ appears to be a load balancer – http://www.nextthing.org/archives/2005/08/07/fun-with-http-headers

item.title: By: Thomas Scholz
item.dc:creator: Thomas Scholz
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/11/01/user-agent-sniffing-at-google-libraries-cdn/#comment-3561">Julien</a>.
Reminds me of FaceBook: You get 'X-Cnection: close' when you try to call an unknown user, e.g.: http://www.facebook.com/people/hammernich/ Oh, and an empty Location header …
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Julien.

Reminds me of FaceBook: You get ‘X-Cnection: close’ when you try to call an unknown user, e.g.: http://www.facebook.com/people/hammernich/
Oh, and an empty Location header …

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/11/01/user-agent-sniffing-at-google-libraries-cdn/#comment-3564">Steve Souders</a>.
Thanks. As for a whitelist approach, are there really that many new HTTP clients coming out that have broken compression support? If most of the broken ones are older then it seems like less work to simply black list known problem clients. As the Opera item highlights, there is often little motivation in updating a white list. A black list might cause more pain in the short term (when a new broken client shows up), but that pain would lead to motivation in making sure the list is up to date.
Making the white list that Google Library is using to determine feature support public would be really helpful. Including test methodologies and contact info for sending in updates would allow others to help keep the list up to date.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Steve Souders.

Thanks. As for a whitelist approach, are there really that many new HTTP clients coming out that have broken compression support? If most of the broken ones are older then it seems like less work to simply black list known problem clients. As the Opera item highlights, there is often little motivation in updating a white list. A black list might cause more pain in the short term (when a new broken client shows up), but that pain would lead to motivation in making sure the list is up to date.

Making the white list that Google Library is using to determine feature support public would be really helpful. Including test methodologies and contact info for sending in updates would allow others to help keep the list up to date.

item.title: By: Steve Souders
item.dc:creator: Steve Souders
item.description: Great post, Joseph! Using a whitelist even in the presence of Accept-Encoding has merit (I discuss this in HPWS). However, Opera should be in the whitelist afaik. I'll contact the Google Libraries API folks.
item.content:encoded: Great post, Joseph! Using a whitelist even in the presence of Accept-Encoding has merit (I discuss this in HPWS). However, Opera should be in the whitelist afaik. I’ll contact the Google Libraries API folks.

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/11/01/user-agent-sniffing-at-google-libraries-cdn/#comment-3561">Julien</a>.
Interesting, I'll have to look closer at the Connection header behavior in more detail at some point.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Julien.

Interesting, I’ll have to look closer at the Connection header behavior in more detail at some point.

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/11/01/user-agent-sniffing-at-google-libraries-cdn/#comment-3560">Thomas Scholz</a>.
I'm not sure if it is reason enough to avoid using the Google Library CDN, but it does raise a few more questions.
As for Hoffman's post, he brings up good points, but tries to apply them way too broadly. To say that avoiding a CDN for your Javascript files is the right answer for every site on the web is over simplifying by a long (LONG) shot.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Thomas Scholz.

I’m not sure if it is reason enough to avoid using the Google Library CDN, but it does raise a few more questions.

As for Hoffman’s post, he brings up good points, but tries to apply them way too broadly. To say that avoiding a CDN for your Javascript files is the right answer for every site on the web is over simplifying by a long (LONG) shot.

item.title: By: Julien
item.dc:creator: Julien
item.description: We actually found out that many servers do similar things. We have the same pattern with the 'Connection: Close' header. Some servers will automatically close the connection based on the UA (browsers mostly), or will keep it alive (Bots).
item.content:encoded: We actually found out that many servers do similar things. We have the same pattern with the ‘Connection: Close’ header. Some servers will automatically close the connection based on the UA (browsers mostly), or will keep it alive (Bots).
